newsitem.title: CANADA: Union predicts lengthy Fletcher strike.
newsitem.headline: Union predicts lengthy Fletcher strike.

text.p: A strike due to begin next Monday at Fletcher Challenge Canada Ltd's three British Columbia pulp and paper mills will likely last months and be very costly to the company, a union official said on Tuesday.

"I think it could be a long time, much longer than normal. By that I mean months, not weeks...and run into millions and millions of dollars," said Brian Payne of the Communications, Energy and Paperworkers (CEP) union.
The CEP and Fletcher's other union, the Pulp, Paper and Woodworkers of Canada, have said they will go on strike July 14 after contract talks collapsed on Tuesday.
The strike would be the second in 2-1/2 years for Fletcher, whose mills were shut by a six-week strike in late 1994 and early 1995.
Payne said the strike would hurt the company because it comes amid a time of rising pulp and paper prices and would hurt the continuity of supply to Fletcher customers.
Fletcher negotiator Howard Burleigh was unable to estimate immediately how much the strike could cost the company.
The three mills have capacity to produce 930,000 tonnes of newsprint, 730,000 tonnes of market pulp and 90,000 tonnes of containerboard a year.
The 2,400 unionized workers have been without a contract since April.
For the unions, the "deal breaker" in this round of negotiations was Fletcher's insistence on so-called full flexibility, Payne said.
That would allow the company to assign employees work outside their normal job classifications, he said. Maintenence workers would be the most affected.

Fletcher is also seeking to operate 365 days a year instead of the current 362 days, and concessions on contract language that protects workers from layoffs if outside contractors are used, Payne said.
He said the union was prepared to bargain a longer than normal contract in return for concessions from Fletcher in other areas.

The last proposal from the union was for a three-year agreement, while Fletcher sought a six-year deal. Fletcher said the union wanted a five percent a year wage hike, while the company was offering a one percent a year raise.
Fletcher is majority owned by New Zealand's Fletcher Challenge Ltd.
